2295  // We must ensure that continuations off _OuterTask (especially exception handling ones) continue to function in the
2296  // presence of an exception flowing out of the inner task _UnwrappedTask. This requires an exception handling continuation
2297  // off the inner task which does the appropriate funnelling to the outer one. We use _Then instead of then to prevent
2298  // the exception from being marked as observed by our internal continuation. This continuation must be scheduled regardless
2299  // of whether or not the _OuterTask task is canceled.
2300  //
2301  _UnwrappedTask._Then([_OuterTask] (task<_InternalReturnType> _AncestorTask) {
2302 
2303  if (_AncestorTask._GetImpl()->_IsCompleted())
2304  {
2305  _OuterTask->_FinalizeAndRunContinuations(_AncestorTask._GetImpl()->_GetResult());
2306  }
2307  else
2308  {
2309  _ASSERTE(_AncestorTask._GetImpl()->_IsCanceled());
2310  if (_AncestorTask._GetImpl()->_HasUserException())
2311  {
2312  // Set _PropagatedFromAncestor to false, since _AncestorTask is not an ancestor of _UnwrappedTask.
2313  // Instead, it is the enclosing task.
2314  _OuterTask->_CancelWithExceptionHolder(_AncestorTask._GetImpl()->_GetExceptionHolder(), false);
2315  }
2316  else
2317  {
2318  _OuterTask->_Cancel(true);
2319  }
2320  }
2321  }, nullptr, details::_DefaultAutoInline);
2322 
2323  }
2324 
2325  scheduler_ptr _GetScheduler() const
2326  {
2327  return _M_TaskCollection._GetScheduler();
2328  }
2329 
2330  // Tracks the internal state of the task
2331  volatile _TaskInternalState _M_TaskState;
2332  // Set to true either if the ancestor task had the flag set to true, or if the lambda that does the work of this task returns an
2333  // async operation or async action that is unwrapped by the runtime.
2334  bool _M_fFromAsync;
2335  // Set to true when a continuation unwraps a task or async operation.
2336  bool _M_fUnwrappedTask;
2337 
2338  // An exception thrown by the task body is captured in an exception holder and it is shared with all value based continuations rooted at the task.
2339  // The exception is 'observed' if the user invokes get()/wait() on any of the tasks that are sharing this exception holder. If the exception
2340  // is not observed by the time the internal object owned by the shared pointer destructs, the process will fail fast.
2341  std::shared_ptr<_ExceptionHolder> _M_exceptionHolder;
2342 
2343  ::pplx::extensibility::critical_section_t _M_ContinuationsCritSec;
2344 
2345  // The cancellation token state.
2346  _CancellationTokenState * _M_pTokenState;
2347 
2348  // The registration on the token.
2349  _CancellationTokenRegistration * _M_pRegistration;
2350 
2351  typedef _ContinuationTaskHandleBase * _ContinuationList;
2352  _ContinuationList _M_Continuations;
2353 
2354  // The async task collection wrapper
2355  ::pplx::details::_TaskCollection_t _M_TaskCollection;
2356 
2357  // Callstack for function call (constructor or .then) that created this task impl.
2358  _TaskCreationCallstack _M_pTaskCreationCallstack;
2359 
2360  _TaskEventLogger _M_taskEventLogger;
2361  private:
2362  // Must not be copied by value:
2363  _Task_impl_base(const _Task_impl_base&);
2364  _Task_impl_base const & operator=(_Task_impl_base const&);
2365  };
2366 
2367 #if _PPLTASK_ASYNC_LOGGING
2368  inline void _TaskEventLogger::_LogTaskCompleted()
2369  {
2370  if (_M_scheduled)
2371  {
2372  ::Windows::Foundation::AsyncStatus _State;
2373  if (_M_task->_IsCompleted())
2374  _State = ::Windows::Foundation::AsyncStatus::Completed;
2375  else if (_M_task->_HasUserException())
2376  _State = ::Windows::Foundation::AsyncStatus::Error;
2377  else
2378  _State = ::Windows::Foundation::AsyncStatus::Canceled;
2379 
2380  if (details::_IsCausalitySupported())
2381  {
2382  ::Windows::Foundation::Diagnostics::AsyncCausalityTracer::TraceOperationCompletion(::Windows::Foundation::Diagnostics::CausalityTraceLevel::Required, ::Windows::Foundation::Diagnostics::CausalitySource::Library,
2383  _PPLTaskCausalityPlatformID, reinterpret_cast<unsigned long long>(_M_task), _State);
2384  }
2385  }
2386  }
2387 #endif
2388 
2389  /// <summary>
2390  /// The implementation of a first-class task. This structure contains the task group used to execute
2391  /// the task function and handles the scheduling. The _Task_impl is created as a shared_ptr
2392  /// member of the the public task class, so its destruction is handled automatically.
2393  /// </summary>
2394  /// <typeparam name="_ReturnType">
2395  /// The result type of this task.
2396  /// </typeparam>
2397  /**/
2398  template<typename _ReturnType>
2399  struct _Task_impl : public _Task_impl_base
2400  {
2401 #if defined (__cplusplus_winrt)
2402  typedef Windows::Foundation::IAsyncOperation<typename details::_ValueTypeOrRefType<_ReturnType>::_Value> _AsyncOperationType;
2403 #endif // defined(__cplusplus_winrt)
2404  _Task_impl(_CancellationTokenState * _Ct, scheduler_ptr _Scheduler_arg)
2405  : _Task_impl_base(_Ct, _Scheduler_arg)
2406  {
2407 #if defined (__cplusplus_winrt)
2408  _M_unwrapped_async_op = nullptr;
2409 #endif /* defined (__cplusplus_winrt) */
2410  }
2411 
2412  virtual ~_Task_impl()
2413  {
2414  // We must invoke _DeregisterCancellation in the derived class destructor. Calling it in the base class destructor could cause
2415  // a partially initialized _Task_impl to be in the list of registrations for a cancellation token.
2416  _DeregisterCancellation();
2417  }
2418 
2419  virtual bool _CancelAndRunContinuations(bool _SynchronousCancel, bool _UserException, bool _PropagatedFromAncestor, const std::shared_ptr<_ExceptionHolder> & _ExceptionHolder_arg)
2420  {
2421  bool _RunContinuations = false;
2422  {
2423  ::pplx::extensibility::scoped_critical_section_t _LockHolder(_M_ContinuationsCritSec);
2424  if (_UserException)
2425  {
2426  _ASSERTE(_SynchronousCancel && !_IsCompleted());
2427  // If the state is _Canceled, the exception has to be coming from an ancestor.
2428  _ASSERTE(!_IsCanceled() || _PropagatedFromAncestor);
2429 
2430  // We should not be canceled with an exception more than once.
2431  _ASSERTE(!_HasUserException());
2432 
2433  // Mark _PropagatedFromAncestor as used.
2434  (void)_PropagatedFromAncestor;
2435 
2436  if (_M_TaskState == _Canceled)
2437  {
2438  // If the task has finished cancelling there should not be any continuation records in the array.
2439  return false;
2440  }
2441  else
2442  {
2443  _ASSERTE(_M_TaskState != _Completed);
2444  _M_exceptionHolder = _ExceptionHolder_arg;
2445  }
2446  }
2447  else
2448  {
2449  // Completed is a non-cancellable state, and if this is an asynchronous cancel, we're unable to do better than the last async cancel
2450  // which is to say, cancellation is already initiated, so return early.
2451  if (_IsCompleted() || _IsCanceled() || (_IsPendingCancel() && !_SynchronousCancel))
2452  {
2453  _ASSERTE(!_IsCompleted() || !_HasUserException());
2454  return false;
2455  }
2456  _ASSERTE(!_SynchronousCancel || !_HasUserException());
2457  }
2458 
2459  if (_SynchronousCancel)
2460  {
2461  // Be aware that this set must be done BEFORE _M_Scheduled being set, or race will happen between this and wait()
2462  _M_TaskState = _Canceled;
2463  // Cancellation completes the task, so all dependent tasks must be run to cancel them
2464  // They are canceled when they begin running (see _RunContinuation) and see that their
2465  // ancestor has been canceled.
2466  _RunContinuations = true;
2467  }
2468  else
2469  {
2470  _ASSERTE(!_UserException);
2471 
2472  if (_IsStarted())
2473  {
2474 #if defined (__cplusplus_winrt)
2475  if (_M_unwrapped_async_op != nullptr)
2476  {
2477  // We will only try to cancel async operation but not unwrapped tasks, since unwrapped tasks cannot be canceled without its token.
2478  _M_unwrapped_async_op->Cancel();
2479  }
2480 #endif /* defined (__cplusplus_winrt) */
2481  _M_TaskCollection._Cancel();
2482  }
2483 
2484  // The _M_TaskState variable transitions to _Canceled when cancellation is completed (the task is not executing user code anymore).
2485  // In the case of a synchronous cancel, this can happen immediately, whereas with an asynchronous cancel, the task has to move from
2486  // _Started to _PendingCancel before it can move to _Canceled when it is finished executing.
2487  _M_TaskState = _PendingCancel;
2488 
2489  _M_taskEventLogger._LogCancelTask();
2490  }
2491 
2492 
2493  }
2494 
2495  // Only execute continuations and mark the task as completed if we were able to move the task to the _Canceled state.
2496  if (_RunContinuations)
2497  {
2498  _M_TaskCollection._Complete();
2499 
2500  if (_M_Continuations)
2501  {
2502  // Scheduling cancellation with automatic inlining.
2503  _ScheduleFuncWithAutoInline([=](){ _RunTaskContinuations(); }, details::_DefaultAutoInline);
2504  }
2505  }
2506  return true;
2507  }
2508 
2509  void _FinalizeAndRunContinuations(_ReturnType _Result)
2510  {
2511  _M_Result.Set(_Result);
2512 
2513  {
2514  //
2515  // Hold this lock to ensure continuations being concurrently either get added
2516  // to the _M_Continuations vector or wait for the result
2517  //
2518  ::pplx::extensibility::scoped_critical_section_t _LockHolder(_M_ContinuationsCritSec);
2519 
2520  // A task could still be in the _Created state if it was created with a task_completion_event.
2521  // It could also be in the _Canceled state for the same reason.
2522  _ASSERTE(!_HasUserException() && !_IsCompleted());
2523  if (_IsCanceled())
2524  {
2525  return;
2526  }
2527 
2528  // Always transition to "completed" state, even in the face of unacknowledged pending cancellation
2529  _M_TaskState = _Completed;
2530  }
2531  _M_TaskCollection._Complete();
2532  _RunTaskContinuations();
2533  }
2534 
2535  //
2536  // This method is invoked when the starts executing. The task returns early if this method returns true.
2537  //
2538  bool _TransitionedToStarted()
2539  {
2540  ::pplx::extensibility::scoped_critical_section_t _LockHolder(_M_ContinuationsCritSec);
2541  // Canceled state could only result from antecedent task's canceled state, but that code path will not reach here.
2542  _ASSERTE(!_IsCanceled());
2543  if (_IsPendingCancel())
2544  return false;
2545 
2546  _ASSERTE(_IsCreated());
2547  _M_TaskState = _Started;
2548  return true;
2549  }
2550 
2551 #if defined (__cplusplus_winrt)
2552  void _SetUnwrappedAsyncOp(_AsyncOperationType^ _AsyncOp)
2553  {
2554  ::pplx::extensibility::scoped_critical_section_t _LockHolder(_M_ContinuationsCritSec);
2555  // Cancel the async operation if the task itself is canceled, since the thread that canceled the task missed it.
2556  if (_IsPendingCancel())
2557  {
2558  _ASSERTE(!_IsCanceled());
2559  _AsyncOp->Cancel();
2560  }
2561  else
2562  {
2563  _M_unwrapped_async_op = _AsyncOp;
2564  }
2565  }
2566 #endif /* defined (__cplusplus_winrt) */
2567 
2568  // Return true if the task has reached a terminal state
2569  bool _IsDone()
2570  {
2571  return _IsCompleted() || _IsCanceled();
2572  }
2573 
2574  _ReturnType _GetResult()
2575  {
2576  return _M_Result.Get();
2577  }
2578 
2579  _ResultHolder<_ReturnType> _M_Result; // this means that the result type must have a public default ctor.
2580 #if defined (__cplusplus_winrt)
2581  _AsyncOperationType^ _M_unwrapped_async_op;
2582 #endif /* defined (__cplusplus_winrt) */
2583  };
2584 
2585  template<typename _ResultType>
2586  struct _Task_completion_event_impl
2587  {
2588  private:
2589  _Task_completion_event_impl(const _Task_completion_event_impl&);
2590  _Task_completion_event_impl& operator=(const _Task_completion_event_impl&);
2591 
2592  public:
2593 
2594  typedef std::vector<typename _Task_ptr<_ResultType>::_Type> _TaskList;
2595 
2596  _Task_completion_event_impl() :
2597  _M_fHasValue(false), _M_fIsCanceled(false)
2598  {
2599  }
2600 
2601  bool _HasUserException()
2602  {
2603  return _M_exceptionHolder != nullptr;
2604  }
2605 
2606  ~_Task_completion_event_impl()
2607  {
2608  for( auto _TaskIt = _M_tasks.begin(); _TaskIt != _M_tasks.end(); ++_TaskIt )
2609  {
2610  _ASSERTE(!_M_fHasValue && !_M_fIsCanceled);
2611  // Cancel the tasks since the event was never signaled or canceled.
2612  (*_TaskIt)->_Cancel(true);
2613  }
2614  }
2615 
2616  // We need to protect the loop over the array, so concurrent_vector would not have helped
2617  _TaskList _M_tasks;
2618  ::pplx::extensibility::critical_section_t _M_taskListCritSec;
2619  _ResultHolder<_ResultType> _M_value;
2620  std::shared_ptr<_ExceptionHolder> _M_exceptionHolder;
2621  bool _M_fHasValue;
2622  bool _M_fIsCanceled;
2623  };
2624 
2625  // Utility method for dealing with void functions
2626  inline std::function<_Unit_type(void)> _MakeVoidToUnitFunc(const std::function<void(void)>& _Func)
2627  {
2628  return [=]() -> _Unit_type { _Func(); return _Unit_type(); };
2629  }
2630 
2631  template <typename _Type>
2632  std::function<_Type(_Unit_type)> _MakeUnitToTFunc(const std::function<_Type(void)>& _Func)
2633  {
2634  return [=](_Unit_type) -> _Type { return _Func(); };
2635  }
2636 
2637  template <typename _Type>
2638  std::function<_Unit_type(_Type)> _MakeTToUnitFunc(const std::function<void(_Type)>& _Func)
2639  {
2640  return [=](_Type t) -> _Unit_type { _Func(t); return _Unit_type(); };
2641  }
2642 
2643  inline std::function<_Unit_type(_Unit_type)> _MakeUnitToUnitFunc(const std::function<void(void)>& _Func)
2644  {
2645  return [=](_Unit_type) -> _Unit_type { _Func(); return _Unit_type(); };
2646  }
2647 } // namespace details
2648 
2649 /// <summary>
2650 /// The <c>task_completion_event</c> class allows you to delay the execution of a task until a condition is satisfied,
2651 /// or start a task in response to an external event.
2652 /// </summary>
2653 /// <typeparam name="_ResultType">
2654 /// The result type of this <c>task_completion_event</c> class.
2655 /// </typeparam>
2656 /// <remarks>
2657 /// Use a task created from a task completion event when your scenario requires you to create a task that will complete, and
2658 /// thereby have its continuations scheduled for execution, at some point in the future. The <c>task_completion_event</c> must
2659 /// have the same type as the task you create, and calling the set method on the task completion event with a value of that type
2660 /// will cause the associated task to complete, and provide that value as a result to its continuations.
2661 /// <para>If the task completion event is never signaled, any tasks created from it will be canceled when it is destructed.</para>
2662 /// <para><c>task_completion_event</c> behaves like a smart pointer, and should be passed by value.</para>
2663 /// </remarks>
2664 /// <seealso cref="task Class"/>
2665 /**/
2666 template<typename _ResultType>
2667 class task_completion_event
2668 {
2669 public:
2670  /// <summary>
2671  /// Constructs a <c>task_completion_event</c> object.
2672  /// </summary>
2673  /**/
2674  task_completion_event()
2675  : _M_Impl(std::make_shared<details::_Task_completion_event_impl<_ResultType>>())
2676  {
2677  }
2678 
2679  /// <summary>
2680  /// Sets the task completion event.
2681  /// </summary>
2682  /// <param name="_Result">
2683  /// The result to set this event with.
2684  /// </param>
2685  /// <returns>
2686  /// The method returns <c>true</c> if it was successful in setting the event. It returns <c>false</c> if the event is already set.
2687  /// </returns>
2688  /// <remarks>
2689  /// In the presence of multiple or concurrent calls to <c>set</c>, only the first call will succeed and its result (if any) will be stored in the
2690  /// task completion event. The remaining sets are ignored and the method will return false. When you set a task completion event, all the
2691  /// tasks created from that event will immediately complete, and its continuations, if any, will be scheduled. Task completion objects that have
2692  /// a <typeparamref name="_ResultType"/> other than <c>void</c> will pass the value <paramref value="_Result"/> to their continuations.
2693  /// </remarks>
2694  /**/
2695  bool set(_ResultType _Result) const // 'const' (even though it's not deep) allows to safely pass events by value into lambdas
2696  {
2697  // Subsequent sets are ignored. This makes races to set benign: the first setter wins and all others are ignored.
2698  if (_IsTriggered())
2699  {
2700  return false;
2701  }
2702 
2703  _TaskList _Tasks;
2704  bool _RunContinuations = false;
2705  {
2706  ::pplx::extensibility::scoped_critical_section_t _LockHolder(_M_Impl->_M_taskListCritSec);
2707 
2708  if (!_IsTriggered())
2709  {
2710  _M_Impl->_M_value.Set(_Result);
2711  _M_Impl->_M_fHasValue = true;
2712 
2713  _Tasks.swap(_M_Impl->_M_tasks);
2714  _RunContinuations = true;
2715  }
2716  }
2717 
2718  if (_RunContinuations)
2719  {
2720  for( auto _TaskIt = _Tasks.begin(); _TaskIt != _Tasks.end(); ++_TaskIt )
2721  {
2722  // If current task was cancelled by a cancellation_token, it would be in cancel pending state.
2723  if ((*_TaskIt)->_IsPendingCancel())
2724  (*_TaskIt)->_Cancel(true);
2725  else
2726  {
2727  // Tasks created with task_completion_events can be marked as async, (we do this in when_any and when_all
2728  // if one of the tasks involved is an async task). Since continuations of async tasks can execute inline, we
2729  // need to run continuations after the lock is released.
2730  (*_TaskIt)->_FinalizeAndRunContinuations(_M_Impl->_M_value.Get());
2731  }
2732  }
2733  if (_M_Impl->_HasUserException())
2734  {
2735  _M_Impl->_M_exceptionHolder.reset();
2736  }
2737  return true;
2738  }
2739 
2740  return false;
2741  }
2742 
2743  template<typename _E>
2744  __declspec(noinline) // Ask for no inlining so that the _ReturnAddress intrinsic gives us the expected result
2745  bool set_exception(_E _Except) const // 'const' (even though it's not deep) allows to safely pass events by value into lambdas
2746  {
2747  // It is important that _CAPTURE_CALLSTACK() evaluate to the instruction after the call instruction for set_exception.
2748  return _Cancel(std::make_exception_ptr(_Except), _CAPTURE_CALLSTACK());
2749  }
2750 
2751  /// <summary>
2752  /// Propagates an exception to all tasks associated with this event.
2753  /// </summary>
2754  /// <param>
2755  /// The exception_ptr that indicates the exception to set this event with.
2756  /// </param>
2757  /**/
2758  __declspec(noinline) // Ask for no inlining so that the _CAPTURE_CALLSTACK gives us the expected result
2759  bool set_exception(std::exception_ptr _ExceptionPtr) const // 'const' (even though it's not deep) allows to safely pass events by value into lambdas
2760  {
2761  // It is important that _CAPTURE_CALLSTACK() evaluate to the instruction after the call instruction for set_exception.
2762  return _Cancel(_ExceptionPtr, _CAPTURE_CALLSTACK());
2763  }
2764 
2765  /// <summary>
2766  /// Internal method to cancel the task_completion_event. Any task created using this event will be marked as canceled if it has
2767  /// not already been set.
2768  /// </summary>
2769  bool _Cancel() const
2770  {
2771  // Cancel with the stored exception if one exists.
2772  return _CancelInternal();
2773  }
2774 
2775  /// <summary>
2776  /// Internal method to cancel the task_completion_event with the exception provided. Any task created using this event will be canceled
2777  /// with the same exception.
2778  /// </summary>
2779  template<typename _ExHolderType>
2780  bool _Cancel(_ExHolderType _ExHolder, const details::_TaskCreationCallstack &_SetExceptionAddressHint = details::_TaskCreationCallstack ()) const
2781  {
2782  bool _Canceled;
2783  if(_StoreException(_ExHolder, _SetExceptionAddressHint))
2784  {
2785  _Canceled = _CancelInternal();
2786  _ASSERTE(_Canceled);
2787  }
2788  else
2789  {
2790  _Canceled = false;
2791  }
2792  return _Canceled;
2793  }
2794 
2795  /// <summary>
2796  /// Internal method that stores an exception in the task completion event. This is used internally by when_any.
2797  /// Note, this does not cancel the task completion event. A task completion event with a stored exception
2798  /// can bet set() successfully. If it is canceled, it will cancel with the stored exception, if one is present.
2799  /// </summary>
2800  template<typename _ExHolderType>
2801  bool _StoreException(_ExHolderType _ExHolder, const details::_TaskCreationCallstack &_SetExceptionAddressHint = details::_TaskCreationCallstack ()) const
2802  {
2803  ::pplx::extensibility::scoped_critical_section_t _LockHolder(_M_Impl->_M_taskListCritSec);
2804  if (!_IsTriggered() && !_M_Impl->_HasUserException())
2805  {
2806  // Create the exception holder only if we have ensured there we will be successful in setting it onto the
2807  // task completion event. Failing to do so will result in an unobserved task exception.
2808  _M_Impl->_M_exceptionHolder = _ToExceptionHolder(_ExHolder, _SetExceptionAddressHint);
2809  return true;
2810  }
2811  return false;
2812  }
2813 
2814  /// <summary>
2815  /// Tests whether current event has been either Set, or Canceled.
2816  /// </summary>
2817  bool _IsTriggered() const
2818  {
2819  return _M_Impl->_M_fHasValue || _M_Impl->_M_fIsCanceled;
2820  }
2821 
2822 private:
2823 
2824  static std::shared_ptr<details::_ExceptionHolder> _ToExceptionHolder(const std::shared_ptr<details::_ExceptionHolder>& _ExHolder, const details::_TaskCreationCallstack&)
2825  {
2826  return _ExHolder;
2827  }
2828 
2829  static std::shared_ptr<details::_ExceptionHolder> _ToExceptionHolder(std::exception_ptr _ExceptionPtr, const details::_TaskCreationCallstack &_SetExceptionAddressHint)
2830  {
2831  return std::make_shared<details::_ExceptionHolder>(_ExceptionPtr, _SetExceptionAddressHint);
2832  }
2833 
2834 
2835  template <typename T> friend class task; // task can register itself with the event by calling the private _RegisterTask
2836  template <typename T> friend class task_completion_event;
2837 
2838  typedef typename details::_Task_completion_event_impl<_ResultType>::_TaskList _TaskList;
2839 
2840  /// <summary>
2841  /// Cancels the task_completion_event.
2842  /// </summary>
2843  bool _CancelInternal() const
2844  {
2845  // Cancellation of task completion events is an internal only utility. Our usage is such that _CancelInternal
2846  // will never be invoked if the task completion event has been set.
2847  _ASSERTE(!_M_Impl->_M_fHasValue);
2848  if (_M_Impl->_M_fIsCanceled)
2849  {
2850  return false;
2851  }
2852 
2853  _TaskList _Tasks;
2854  bool _Cancel = false;
2855  {
2856  ::pplx::extensibility::scoped_critical_section_t _LockHolder(_M_Impl->_M_taskListCritSec);
2857  _ASSERTE(!_M_Impl->_M_fHasValue);
2858  if (!_M_Impl->_M_fIsCanceled)
2859  {
2860  _M_Impl->_M_fIsCanceled = true;
2861  _Tasks.swap(_M_Impl->_M_tasks);
2862  _Cancel = true;
2863  }
2864  }
2865 
2866  bool _UserException = _M_Impl->_HasUserException();
2867 
2868  if (_Cancel)
2869  {
2870  for( auto _TaskIt = _Tasks.begin(); _TaskIt != _Tasks.end(); ++_TaskIt )
2871  {
2872  // Need to call this after the lock is released. See comments in set().
2873  if (_UserException)
2874  {
2875  (*_TaskIt)->_CancelWithExceptionHolder(_M_Impl->_M_exceptionHolder, true);
2876  }
2877  else
2878  {
2879  (*_TaskIt)->_Cancel(true);
2880  }
2881  }
2882  }
2883  return _Cancel;
2884  }
2885 
2886  /// <summary>
2887  /// Register a task with this event. This function is called when a task is constructed using
2888  /// a task_completion_event.
2889  /// </summary>
2890  void _RegisterTask(const typename details::_Task_ptr<_ResultType>::_Type & _TaskParam)
2891  {
2892  ::pplx::extensibility::scoped_critical_section_t _LockHolder(_M_Impl->_M_taskListCritSec);
2893 
2894  //If an exception was already set on this event, then cancel the task with the stored exception.
2895  if(_M_Impl->_HasUserException())
2896  {
2897  _TaskParam->_CancelWithExceptionHolder(_M_Impl->_M_exceptionHolder, true);
2898  }
2899  else if (_M_Impl->_M_fHasValue)
2900  {
2901  _TaskParam->_FinalizeAndRunContinuations(_M_Impl->_M_value.Get());
2902  }
2903  else
2904  {
2905  _M_Impl->_M_tasks.push_back(_TaskParam);
2906  }
2907  }
2908 
2909  std::shared_ptr<details::_Task_completion_event_impl<_ResultType>> _M_Impl;
2910 };
2911 
2912 /// <summary>
2913 /// The <c>task_completion_event</c> class allows you to delay the execution of a task until a condition is satisfied,
2914 /// or start a task in response to an external event.
2915 /// </summary>
2916 /// <remarks>
2917 /// Use a task created from a task completion event when your scenario requires you to create a task that will complete, and
2918 /// thereby have its continuations scheduled for execution, at some point in the future. The <c>task_completion_event</c> must
2919 /// have the same type as the task you create, and calling the set method on the task completion event with a value of that type
2920 /// will cause the associated task to complete, and provide that value as a result to its continuations.
2921 /// <para>If the task completion event is never signaled, any tasks created from it will be canceled when it is destructed.</para>
2922 /// <para><c>task_completion_event</c> behaves like a smart pointer, and should be passed by value.</para>
2923 /// </remarks>
2924 /// <seealso cref="task Class"/>
2925 /**/
2926 template<>
2927 class task_completion_event<void>
2928 {
2929 public:
2930  /// <summary>
2931  /// Sets the task completion event.
2932  /// </summary>
2933  /// <returns>
2934  /// The method returns <c>true</c> if it was successful in setting the event. It returns <c>false</c> if the event is already set.
2935  /// </returns>
2936  /// <remarks>
2937  /// In the presence of multiple or concurrent calls to <c>set</c>, only the first call will succeed and its result (if any) will be stored in the
2938  /// task completion event. The remaining sets are ignored and the method will return false. When you set a task completion event, all the
2939  /// tasks created from that event will immediately complete, and its continuations, if any, will be scheduled. Task completion objects that have
2940  /// a <typeparamref name="_ResultType"/> other than <c>void</c> will pass the value <paramref value="_Result"/> to their continuations.
2941  /// </remarks>
2942  /**/
2943  bool set() const // 'const' (even though it's not deep) allows to safely pass events by value into lambdas
2944  {
2945  return _M_unitEvent.set(details::_Unit_type());
2946  }
2947 
2948  template<typename _E>
2949  __declspec(noinline) // Ask for no inlining so that the _ReturnAddress intrinsic gives us the expected result
2950  bool set_exception(_E _Except) const // 'const' (even though it's not deep) allows to safely pass events by value into lambdas
2951  {
2952  return _M_unitEvent._Cancel(std::make_exception_ptr(_Except), _CAPTURE_CALLSTACK());
2953  }
2954 
2955  /// <summary>
2956  /// Propagates an exception to all tasks associated with this event.
2957  /// </summary>
2958  /// <param>
2959  /// The exception_ptr that indicates the exception to set this event with.
2960  /// </param>
2961  /**/
2962  __declspec(noinline) // Ask for no inlining so that the _CAPTURE_CALLSTACK intrinsic gives us the expected result
2963  bool set_exception(std::exception_ptr _ExceptionPtr) const // 'const' (even though it's not deep) allows to safely pass events by value into lambdas
2964  {
2965  // It is important that _CAPTURE_CALLSTACK() evaluate to the instruction after the call instruction for set_exception.
2966  return _M_unitEvent._Cancel(_ExceptionPtr, _CAPTURE_CALLSTACK());
2967  }
2968 
2969  /// <summary>
2970  /// Cancel the task_completion_event. Any task created using this event will be marked as canceled if it has
2971  /// not already been set.
2972  /// </summary>
2973  void _Cancel() const // 'const' (even though it's not deep) allows to safely pass events by value into lambdas
2974  {
2975  _M_unitEvent._Cancel();
2976  }
2977 
2978  /// <summary>
2979  /// Cancel the task_completion_event with the exception holder provided. Any task created using this event will be canceled
2980  /// with the same exception.
2981  /// </summary>
2982  void _Cancel(const std::shared_ptr<details::_ExceptionHolder>& _ExHolder) const
2983  {
2984  _M_unitEvent._Cancel(_ExHolder);
2985  }
2986 
2987  /// <summary>
2988  /// Method that stores an exception in the task completion event. This is used internally by when_any.
2989  /// Note, this does not cancel the task completion event. A task completion event with a stored exception
2990  /// can bet set() successfully. If it is canceled, it will cancel with the stored exception, if one is present.
2991  /// </summary>
2992  bool _StoreException(const std::shared_ptr<details::_ExceptionHolder>& _ExHolder) const
2993  {
2994  return _M_unitEvent._StoreException(_ExHolder);
2995  }
2996 
2997  /// <summary>
2998  /// Test whether current event has been either Set, or Canceled.
2999  /// </summary>
3000  bool _IsTriggered() const
3001  {
3002  return _M_unitEvent._IsTriggered();
3003  }
3004 
3005 private:
3006  template <typename T> friend class task; // task can register itself with the event by calling the private _RegisterTask
3007 
3008  /// <summary>
3009  /// Register a task with this event. This function is called when a task is constructed using
3010  /// a task_completion_event.
3011  /// </summary>
3012  void _RegisterTask(details::_Task_ptr<details::_Unit_type>::_Type _TaskParam)
3013  {
3014  _M_unitEvent._RegisterTask(_TaskParam);
3015  }
3016 
3017  // The void event contains an event a dummy type so common code can be used for events with void and non-void results.
3018  task_completion_event<details::_Unit_type> _M_unitEvent;
3019 };
3020 
3021 namespace details
3022 {
3023  //
3024  // Compile-time validation helpers
3025  //
3026 
3027  // Task constructor validation: issue helpful diagnostics for common user errors. Do not attempt full validation here.
3028  //
3029  // Anything callable is fine
3030  template<typename _ReturnType, typename _Ty>
3031  auto _IsValidTaskCtor(_Ty _Param, int,int,int,int) -> decltype(_Param(), std::true_type());
3032 
3033 #if defined (__cplusplus_winrt)
3034  // Anything that has GetResults is fine: this covers all async operations
3035  template<typename _ReturnType, typename _Ty>
3036  auto _IsValidTaskCtor(_Ty _Param, int, int, int,...) -> decltype(_Param->GetResults(), std::true_type());
3037 #endif
3038 
3039  // Allow parameters with set: this covers task_completion_event
3040  template<typename _ReturnType, typename _Ty>
3041  auto _IsValidTaskCtor(_Ty _Param, int, int, ...) -> decltype(_Param.set(stdx::declval<_ReturnType>()), std::true_type());
3042 
3043  template<typename _ReturnType, typename _Ty>
3044  auto _IsValidTaskCtor(_Ty _Param, int, ...) -> decltype(_Param.set(), std::true_type());
3045 
3046  // All else is invalid
3047  template<typename _ReturnType, typename _Ty>
3048  std::false_type _IsValidTaskCtor(_Ty _Param, ...);
3049 
3050  template<typename _ReturnType, typename _Ty>
3051  void _ValidateTaskConstructorArgs(_Ty _Param)
3052  {
3053  static_assert(std::is_same<decltype(_IsValidTaskCtor<_ReturnType>(_Param,0,0,0,0)),std::true_type>::value,
3054 #if defined (__cplusplus_winrt)
3055  "incorrect argument for task constructor; can be a callable object, an asynchronous operation, or a task_completion_event"
3056 #else /* defined (__cplusplus_winrt) */
3057  "incorrect argument for task constructor; can be a callable object or a task_completion_event"
3058 #endif /* defined (__cplusplus_winrt) */
3059  );
3060 #if defined (__cplusplus_winrt)
3061  static_assert(!(std::is_same<_Ty,_ReturnType>::value && details::_IsIAsyncInfo<_Ty>::_Value),
3062  "incorrect template argument for task; consider using the return type of the async operation");
3063 #endif /* defined (__cplusplus_winrt) */
3064  }
3065 
3066 #if defined (__cplusplus_winrt)
3067  // Helpers for create_async validation
3068  //
3069  // A parameter lambda taking no arguments is valid
3070  template<typename _Ty>
3071  static auto _IsValidCreateAsync(_Ty _Param, int, int, int, int) -> decltype(_Param(), std::true_type());
3072 
3073  // A parameter lambda taking an cancellation_token argument is valid
3074  template<typename _Ty>
3075  static auto _IsValidCreateAsync(_Ty _Param, int, int, int, ...) -> decltype(_Param(cancellation_token::none()), std::true_type());
3076 
3077  // A parameter lambda taking a progress report argument is valid
3078  template<typename _Ty>
3079  static auto _IsValidCreateAsync(_Ty _Param, int, int, ...) -> decltype(_Param(details::_ProgressReporterCtorArgType()), std::true_type());
3080 
3081  // A parameter lambda taking a progress report and a cancellation_token argument is valid
3082  template<typename _Ty>
3083  static auto _IsValidCreateAsync(_Ty _Param, int, ...) -> decltype(_Param(details::_ProgressReporterCtorArgType(), cancellation_token::none()), std::true_type());
3084 
3085  // All else is invalid
3086  template<typename _Ty>
3087  static std::false_type _IsValidCreateAsync(_Ty _Param, ...);
3088 #endif /* defined (__cplusplus_winrt) */
3089 }
3090 /// <summary>
3091 /// A helper class template that transforms a continuation lambda that either takes or returns void, or both, into a lambda that takes and returns a
3092 /// non-void type (details::_Unit_type is used to substitute for void). This is to minimize the special handling required for 'void'.
3093 /// </summary>
3094 template<typename _InpType, typename _OutType>
3095 class _Continuation_func_transformer
3096 {
3097 public:
3098  static auto _Perform(std::function<_OutType(_InpType)> _Func) -> decltype(_Func)
3099  {
3100  return _Func;
3101  }
3102 };
3103 
3104 template<typename _OutType>
3105 class _Continuation_func_transformer<void, _OutType>
3106 {
3107 public:
3108  static auto _Perform(std::function<_OutType(void)> _Func) -> decltype(details::_MakeUnitToTFunc<_OutType>(_Func))
3109  {
3110  return details::_MakeUnitToTFunc<_OutType>(_Func);
3111  }
3112 };
3113 
3114 template<typename _InType>
3115 class _Continuation_func_transformer<_InType, void>
3116 {
3117 public:
3118  static auto _Perform(std::function<void(_InType)> _Func) -> decltype(details::_MakeTToUnitFunc<_InType>(_Func))
3119  {
3120  return details::_MakeTToUnitFunc<_InType>(_Func);
3121  }
3122 };
3123 
3124 template<>
3125 class _Continuation_func_transformer<void, void>
3126 {
3127 public:
3128  static auto _Perform(std::function<void(void)> _Func) -> decltype(details::_MakeUnitToUnitFunc(_Func))
3129  {
3130  return details::_MakeUnitToUnitFunc(_Func);
3131  }
3132 };
3133 
3134 // A helper class template that transforms an intial task lambda returns void into a lambda that returns a non-void type (details::_Unit_type is used
3135 // to substitute for void). This is to minimize the special handling required for 'void'.
3136 template<typename _RetType>
3137 class _Init_func_transformer
3138 {
3139 public:
3140  static auto _Perform(std::function<_RetType(void)> _Func) -> decltype(_Func)
3141  {
3142  return _Func;
3143  }
3144 };
3145 
3146 template<>
3147 class _Init_func_transformer<void>
3148 {
3149 public:
3150  static auto _Perform(std::function<void(void)> _Func) -> decltype(details::_MakeVoidToUnitFunc(_Func))
3151  {
3152  return details::_MakeVoidToUnitFunc(_Func);
3153  }
3154 };
3155 
3156 /// <summary>
3157 /// The Parallel Patterns Library (PPL) <c>task</c> class. A <c>task</c> object represents work that can be executed asynchronously,
3158 /// and concurrently with other tasks and parallel work produced by parallel algorithms in the Concurrency Runtime. It produces
3159 /// a result of type <typeparamref name="_ResultType"/> on successful completion. Tasks of type <c>task&lt;void&gt;</c> produce no result.
3160 /// A task can be waited upon and canceled independently of other tasks. It can also be composed with other tasks using
3161 /// continuations(<c>then</c>), and join(<c>when_all</c>) and choice(<c>when_any</c>) patterns.
3162 /// </summary>
3163 /// <typeparam name="_ReturnType">
3164 /// The result type of this task.
3165 /// </typeparam>
3166 /// <remarks>
3167 /// For more information, see <see cref="Task Parallelism (Concurrency Runtime)"/>.
3168 /// </remarks>
3169 /**/
3170 template<typename _ReturnType>
3171 class task
3172 {
3173 public:
3174  /// <summary>
3175  /// The type of the result an object of this class produces.
3176  /// </summary>
3177  /**/
3178  typedef _ReturnType result_type;
3179 
3180  /// <summary>
3181  /// Constructs a <c>task</c> object.
3182  /// </summary>
3183  /// <remarks>
3184  /// The default constructor for a <c>task</c> is only present in order to allow tasks to be used within containers.
3185  /// A default constructed task cannot be used until you assign a valid task to it. Methods such as <c>get</c>, <c>wait</c> or <c>then</c>
3186  /// will throw an <see cref="invalid_argument Class">invalid_argument</see> exception when called on a default constructed task.
3187  /// <para>A task that is created from a <c>task_completion_event</c> will complete (and have its continuations scheduled) when the task
3188  /// completion event is set.</para>
3189  /// <para>The version of the constructor that takes a cancellation token creates a task that can be canceled using the
3190  /// <c>cancellation_token_source</c> the token was obtained from. Tasks created without a cancellation token are not cancelable.</para>
3191  /// <para>Tasks created from a <c>Windows::Foundation::IAsyncInfo</c> interface or a lambda that returns an <c>IAsyncInfo</c> interface
3192  /// reach their terminal state when the enclosed Windows Runtime asynchronous operation or action completes. Similarly, tasks created
3193  /// from a lamda that returns a <c>task&lt;result_type&gt;</c> reach their terminal state when the inner task reaches its terminal state,
3194  /// and not when the lamda returns.</para>
3195  /// <para><c>task</c> behaves like a smart pointer and is safe to pass around by value. It can be accessed by multiple threads
3196  /// without the need for locks.</para>
3197  /// <para>The constructor overloads that take a Windows::Foundation::IAsyncInfo interface or a lambda returning such an interface, are only available
3198  /// to Windows Store apps.</para>
3199  /// <para>For more information, see <see cref="Task Parallelism (Concurrency Runtime)"/>.</para>
3200  /// </remarks>
3201  /**/
3202  task() : _M_Impl(nullptr)
3203  {
3204  // The default constructor should create a task with a nullptr impl. This is a signal that the
3205  // task is not usable and should throw if any wait(), get() or then() APIs are used.
3206  }
3207 
3208  /// <summary>
3209  /// Constructs a <c>task</c> object.
3210  /// </summary>
3211  /// <typeparam name="_Ty">
3212  /// The type of the parameter from which the task is to be constructed.
3213  /// </typeparam>
3214  /// <param name="_Param">
3215  /// The parameter from which the task is to be constructed. This could be a lambda, a function object, a <c>task_completion_event&lt;result_type&gt;</c>
3216  /// object, or a Windows::Foundation::IAsyncInfo if you are using tasks in your Windows Store app. The lambda or function
3217  /// object should be a type equivalent to <c>std::function&lt;X(void)&gt;</c>, where X can be a variable of type <c>result_type</c>,
3218  /// <c>task&lt;result_type&gt;</c>, or a Windows::Foundation::IAsyncInfo in Windows Store apps.
3219  /// </param>
3220  /// <param name="_Token">
3221  /// The cancellation token to associate with this task. A task created without a cancellation token cannot be canceled. It implicitly receives
3222  /// the token <c>cancellation_token::none()</c>.
3223  /// </param>
3224  /// <remarks>
3225  /// The default constructor for a <c>task</c> is only present in order to allow tasks to be used within containers.
3226  /// A default constructed task cannot be used until you assign a valid task to it. Methods such as <c>get</c>, <c>wait</c> or <c>then</c>
3227  /// will throw an <see cref="invalid_argument Class">invalid_argument</see> exception when called on a default constructed task.
3228  /// <para>A task that is created from a <c>task_completion_event</c> will complete (and have its continuations scheduled) when the task
3229  /// completion event is set.</para>
3230  /// <para>The version of the constructor that takes a cancellation token creates a task that can be canceled using the
3231  /// <c>cancellation_token_source</c> the token was obtained from. Tasks created without a cancellation token are not cancelable.</para>
3232  /// <para>Tasks created from a <c>Windows::Foundation::IAsyncInfo</c> interface or a lambda that returns an <c>IAsyncInfo</c> interface
3233  /// reach their terminal state when the enclosed Windows Runtime asynchronous operation or action completes. Similarly, tasks created
3234  /// from a lamda that returns a <c>task&lt;result_type&gt;</c> reach their terminal state when the inner task reaches its terminal state,
3235  /// and not when the lamda returns.</para>
3236  /// <para><c>task</c> behaves like a smart pointer and is safe to pass around by value. It can be accessed by multiple threads
3237  /// without the need for locks.</para>
3238  /// <para>The constructor overloads that take a Windows::Foundation::IAsyncInfo interface or a lambda returning such an interface, are only available
3239  /// to Windows Store apps.</para>
3240  /// <para>For more information, see <see cref="Task Parallelism (Concurrency Runtime)"/>.</para>
3241  /// </remarks>
3242  /**/
3243  template<typename _Ty>
3244  __declspec(noinline) // Ask for no inlining so that the _CAPTURE_CALLSTACK gives us the expected result
3245  explicit task(_Ty _Param)
3246  {
3247  task_options _TaskOptions;
3248  details::_ValidateTaskConstructorArgs<_ReturnType,_Ty>(_Param);
3249 
3250  _CreateImpl(_TaskOptions.get_cancellation_token()._GetImplValue(), _TaskOptions.get_scheduler());
3251  // Do not move the next line out of this function. It is important that _CAPTURE_CALLSTACK() evaluate to the the call site of the task constructor.
3252  _SetTaskCreationCallstack(_CAPTURE_CALLSTACK());
3253 
3254  _TaskInitMaybeFunctor(_Param, details::_IsCallable(_Param,0));
3255  }
3256 
3257  /// <summary>
3258  /// Constructs a <c>task</c> object.
3259  /// </summary>
3260  /// <typeparam name="_Ty">
3261  /// The type of the parameter from which the task is to be constructed.
3262  /// </typeparam>
3263  /// <param name="_Param">
3264  /// The parameter from which the task is to be constructed. This could be a lambda, a function object, a <c>task_completion_event&lt;result_type&gt;</c>
3265  /// object, or a Windows::Foundation::IAsyncInfo if you are using tasks in your Windows Store app. The lambda or function
3266  /// object should be a type equivalent to <c>std::function&lt;X(void)&gt;</c>, where X can be a variable of type <c>result_type</c>,
3267  /// <c>task&lt;result_type&gt;</c>, or a Windows::Foundation::IAsyncInfo in Windows Store apps.
3268  /// </param>
3269  /// <param name="_TaskOptions">
3270  /// The task options include cancellation token, scheduler etc
3271  /// </param>
3272  /// <remarks>
3273  /// The default constructor for a <c>task</c> is only present in order to allow tasks to be used within containers.
3274  /// A default constructed task cannot be used until you assign a valid task to it. Methods such as <c>get</c>, <c>wait</c> or <c>then</c>
3275  /// will throw an <see cref="invalid_argument Class">invalid_argument</see> exception when called on a default constructed task.
3276  /// <para>A task that is created from a <c>task_completion_event</c> will complete (and have its continuations scheduled) when the task
3277  /// completion event is set.</para>
3278  /// <para>The version of the constructor that takes a cancellation token creates a task that can be canceled using the
3279  /// <c>cancellation_token_source</c> the token was obtained from. Tasks created without a cancellation token are not cancelable.</para>
3280  /// <para>Tasks created from a <c>Windows::Foundation::IAsyncInfo</c> interface or a lambda that returns an <c>IAsyncInfo</c> interface
3281  /// reach their terminal state when the enclosed Windows Runtime asynchronous operation or action completes. Similarly, tasks created
3282  /// from a lamda that returns a <c>task&lt;result_type&gt;</c> reach their terminal state when the inner task reaches its terminal state,
3283  /// and not when the lamda returns.</para>
3284  /// <para><c>task</c> behaves like a smart pointer and is safe to pass around by value. It can be accessed by multiple threads
3285  /// without the need for locks.</para>
3286  /// <para>The constructor overloads that take a Windows::Foundation::IAsyncInfo interface or a lambda returning such an interface, are only available
3287  /// to Windows Store apps.</para>
3288  /// <para>For more information, see <see cref="Task Parallelism (Concurrency Runtime)"/>.</para>
3289  /// </remarks>
3290  /**/
3291  template<typename _Ty>
3292  __declspec(noinline) // Ask for no inlining so that the _CAPTURE_CALLSTACK gives us the expected result
3293  explicit task(_Ty _Param, const task_options &_TaskOptions)
3294  {
3295  details::_ValidateTaskConstructorArgs<_ReturnType,_Ty>(_Param);
3296 
3297  _CreateImpl(_TaskOptions.get_cancellation_token()._GetImplValue(), _TaskOptions.get_scheduler());
3298  // Do not move the next line out of this function. It is important that _CAPTURE_CALLSTACK() evaluate to the the call site of the task constructor.
3299  _SetTaskCreationCallstack(details::_get_internal_task_options(_TaskOptions)._M_hasPresetCreationCallstack ? details::_get_internal_task_options(_TaskOptions)._M_presetCreationCallstack : _CAPTURE_CALLSTACK());
3300 
3301  _TaskInitMaybeFunctor(_Param, details::_IsCallable(_Param,0));
3302  }
3303 
3304  /// <summary>
3305  /// Constructs a <c>task</c> object.
3306  /// </summary>
3307  /// <param name="_Other">
3308  /// The source <c>task</c> object.
3309  /// </param>
3310  /// <remarks>
3311  /// The default constructor for a <c>task</c> is only present in order to allow tasks to be used within containers.
3312  /// A default constructed task cannot be used until you assign a valid task to it. Methods such as <c>get</c>, <c>wait</c> or <c>then</c>
3313  /// will throw an <see cref="invalid_argument Class">invalid_argument</see> exception when called on a default constructed task.
3314  /// <para>A task that is created from a <c>task_completion_event</c> will complete (and have its continuations scheduled) when the task
3315  /// completion event is set.</para>
3316  /// <para>The version of the constructor that takes a cancellation token creates a task that can be canceled using the
3317  /// <c>cancellation_token_source</c> the token was obtained from. Tasks created without a cancellation token are not cancelable.</para>
3318  /// <para>Tasks created from a <c>Windows::Foundation::IAsyncInfo</c> interface or a lambda that returns an <c>IAsyncInfo</c> interface
3319  /// reach their terminal state when the enclosed Windows Runtime asynchronous operation or action completes. Similarly, tasks created
3320  /// from a lamda that returns a <c>task&lt;result_type&gt;</c> reach their terminal state when the inner task reaches its terminal state,
3321  /// and not when the lamda returns.</para>
3322  /// <para><c>task</c> behaves like a smart pointer and is safe to pass around by value. It can be accessed by multiple threads
3323  /// without the need for locks.</para>
3324  /// <para>The constructor overloads that take a Windows::Foundation::IAsyncInfo interface or a lambda returning such an interface, are only available
3325  /// to Windows Store apps.</para>
3326  /// <para>For more information, see <see cref="Task Parallelism (Concurrency Runtime)"/>.</para>
3327  /// </remarks>
3328  /**/
3329  task(const task& _Other): _M_Impl(_Other._M_Impl) {}
3330 
3331  /// <summary>
3332  /// Constructs a <c>task</c> object.
3333  /// </summary>
3334  /// <param name="_Other">
3335  /// The source <c>task</c> object.
3336  /// </param>
3337  /// <remarks>
3338  /// The default constructor for a <c>task</c> is only present in order to allow tasks to be used within containers.
3339  /// A default constructed task cannot be used until you assign a valid task to it. Methods such as <c>get</c>, <c>wait</c> or <c>then</c>
3340  /// will throw an <see cref="invalid_argument Class">invalid_argument</see> exception when called on a default constructed task.
3341  /// <para>A task that is created from a <c>task_completion_event</c> will complete (and have its continuations scheduled) when the task
3342  /// completion event is set.</para>
3343  /// <para>The version of the constructor that takes a cancellation token creates a task that can be canceled using the
3344  /// <c>cancellation_token_source</c> the token was obtained from. Tasks created without a cancellation token are not cancelable.</para>
3345  /// <para>Tasks created from a <c>Windows::Foundation::IAsyncInfo</c> interface or a lambda that returns an <c>IAsyncInfo</c> interface
3346  /// reach their terminal state when the enclosed Windows Runtime asynchronous operation or action completes. Similarly, tasks created
3347  /// from a lamda that returns a <c>task&lt;result_type&gt;</c> reach their terminal state when the inner task reaches its terminal state,
3348  /// and not when the lamda returns.</para>
3349  /// <para><c>task</c> behaves like a smart pointer and is safe to pass around by value. It can be accessed by multiple threads
3350  /// without the need for locks.</para>
3351  /// <para>The constructor overloads that take a Windows::Foundation::IAsyncInfo interface or a lambda returning such an interface, are only available
3352  /// to Windows Store apps.</para>
3353  /// <para>For more information, see <see cref="Task Parallelism (Concurrency Runtime)"/>.</para>
3354  /// </remarks>
3355  /**/
3356  task(task&& _Other): _M_Impl(std::move(_Other._M_Impl)) {}
3357 
3358  /// <summary>
3359  /// Replaces the contents of one <c>task</c> object with another.
3360  /// </summary>
3361  /// <param name="_Other">
3362  /// The source <c>task</c> object.
3363  /// </param>
3364  /// <remarks>
3365  /// As <c>task</c> behaves like a smart pointer, after a copy assignment, this <c>task</c> objects represents the same
3366  /// actual task as <paramref name="_Other"/> does.
3367  /// </remarks>
3368  /**/
3369  task& operator=(const task& _Other)
3370  {
3371  if (this != &_Other)
3372  {
3373  _M_Impl = _Other._M_Impl;
3374  }
3375  return *this;
3376  }
3377 
3378  /// <summary>
3379  /// Replaces the contents of one <c>task</c> object with another.
3380  /// </summary>
3381  /// <param name="_Other">
3382  /// The source <c>task</c> object.
3383  /// </param>
3384  /// <remarks>
3385  /// As <c>task</c> behaves like a smart pointer, after a copy assignment, this <c>task</c> objects represents the same
3386  /// actual task as <paramref name="_Other"/> does.
3387  /// </remarks>
3388  /**/
3389  task& operator=(task&& _Other)
3390  {
3391  if (this != &_Other)
3392  {
3393  _M_Impl = std::move(_Other._M_Impl);
3394  }
3395  return *this;
3396  }
3397 
3398  /// <summary>
3399  /// Adds a continuation task to this task.
3400  /// </summary>
3401  /// <typeparam name="_Function">
3402  /// The type of the function object that will be invoked by this task.
3403  /// </typeparam>
3404  /// <param name="_Func">
3405  /// The continuation function to execute when this task completes. This continuation function must take as input
3406  /// a variable of either <c>result_type</c> or <c>task&lt;result_type&gt;</c>, where <c>result_type</c> is the type
3407  /// of the result this task produces.
3408  /// </param>
3409  /// <returns>
3410  /// The newly created continuation task. The result type of the returned task is determined by what <paramref name="_Func"/> returns.
3411  /// </returns>
3412  /// <remarks>
3413  /// The overloads of <c>then</c> that take a lambda or functor that returns a Windows::Foundation::IAsyncInfo interface, are only available
3414  /// to Windows Store apps.
3415  /// <para>For more information on how to use task continuations to compose asynchronous work, see <see cref="Task Parallelism (Concurrency Runtime)"/>.</para>
3416  /// </remarks>
3417  /**/
3418  template<typename _Function>
3419  __declspec(noinline) // Ask for no inlining so that the _CAPTURE_CALLSTACK gives us the expected result
3420  auto then(const _Function& _Func) const -> typename details::_ContinuationTypeTraits<_Function, _ReturnType>::_TaskOfType
3421  {
3422  task_options _TaskOptions;
3423  details::_get_internal_task_options(_TaskOptions)._set_creation_callstack(_CAPTURE_CALLSTACK());
3424  return _ThenImpl<_ReturnType, _Function>(_Func, _TaskOptions);
3425  }
3426 
3427  /// <summary>
3428  /// Adds a continuation task to this task.
3429  /// </summary>
3430  /// <typeparam name="_Function">
3431  /// The type of the function object that will be invoked by this task.
3432  /// </typeparam>
3433  /// <param name="_Func">
3434  /// The continuation function to execute when this task completes. This continuation function must take as input
3435  /// a variable of either <c>result_type</c> or <c>task&lt;result_type&gt;</c>, where <c>result_type</c> is the type
3436  /// of the result this task produces.
3437  /// </param>
3438  /// <param name="_TaskOptions">
3439  /// The task options include cancellation token, scheduler and continuation context. By default the former 3
3440  /// options are inherited from the antecedent task
3441  /// </param>
3442  /// <returns>
3443  /// The newly created continuation task. The result type of the returned task is determined by what <paramref name="_Func"/> returns.
3444  /// </returns>
3445  /// <remarks>
3446  /// The overloads of <c>then</c> that take a lambda or functor that returns a Windows::Foundation::IAsyncInfo interface, are only available
3447  /// to Windows Store apps.
3448  /// <para>For more information on how to use task continuations to compose asynchronous work, see <see cref="Task Parallelism (Concurrency Runtime)"/>.</para>
3449  /// </remarks>
3450  /**/
3451  template<typename _Function>
3452  __declspec(noinline) // Ask for no inlining so that the _CAPTURE_CALLSTACK gives us the expected result
3453  auto then(const _Function& _Func, task_options _TaskOptions) const -> typename details::_ContinuationTypeTraits<_Function, _ReturnType>::_TaskOfType
3454  {
3455  details::_get_internal_task_options(_TaskOptions)._set_creation_callstack(_CAPTURE_CALLSTACK());
3456  return _ThenImpl<_ReturnType, _Function>(_Func, _TaskOptions);
3457  }
3458 
3459  /// <summary>
3460  /// Adds a continuation task to this task.
3461  /// </summary>
3462  /// <typeparam name="_Function">
3463  /// The type of the function object that will be invoked by this task.
3464  /// </typeparam>
3465  /// <param name="_Func">
3466  /// The continuation function to execute when this task completes. This continuation function must take as input
3467  /// a variable of either <c>result_type</c> or <c>task&lt;result_type&gt;</c>, where <c>result_type</c> is the type
3468  /// of the result this task produces.
3469  /// </param>
3470  /// <param name="_CancellationToken">
3471  /// The cancellation token to associate with the continuation task. A continuation task that is created without a cancellation token will inherit
3472  /// the token of its antecedent task.
3473  /// </param>
3474  /// <param name="_ContinuationContext">
3475  /// A variable that specifies where the continuation should execute. This variable is only useful when used in a Windows Store
3476  /// style app. For more information, see <see cref="task_continuation_context Class">task_continuation_context</see>
3477  /// </param>
3478  /// <returns>
3479  /// The newly created continuation task. The result type of the returned task is determined by what <paramref name="_Func"/> returns.
3480  /// </returns>
3481  /// <remarks>
3482  /// The overloads of <c>then</c> that take a lambda or functor that returns a Windows::Foundation::IAsyncInfo interface, are only available
3483  /// to Windows Store apps.
3484  /// <para>For more information on how to use task continuations to compose asynchronous work, see <see cref="Task Parallelism (Concurrency Runtime)"/>.</para>
3485  /// </remarks>
3486  /**/
3487  template<typename _Function>
3488  __declspec(noinline) // Ask for no inlining so that the _CAPTURE_CALLSTACK gives us the expected result
3489  auto then(const _Function& _Func, cancellation_token _CancellationToken, task_continuation_context _ContinuationContext) const -> typename details::_ContinuationTypeTraits<_Function, _ReturnType>::_TaskOfType
3490  {
3491  task_options _TaskOptions(_CancellationToken, _ContinuationContext);
3492  details::_get_internal_task_options(_TaskOptions)._set_creation_callstack(_CAPTURE_CALLSTACK());
3493  return _ThenImpl<_ReturnType, _Function>(_Func, _TaskOptions);
3494  }
3495 
3496  /// <summary>
3497  /// Waits for this task to reach a terminal state. It is possible for <c>wait</c> to execute the task inline, if all of the tasks
3498  /// dependencies are satisfied, and it has not already been picked up for execution by a background worker.
3499  /// </summary>
3500  /// <returns>
3501  /// A <c>task_status</c> value which could be either <c>completed</c> or <c>canceled</c>. If the task encountered an exception
3502  /// during execution, or an exception was propagated to it from an antecedent task, <c>wait</c> will throw that exception.
3503  /// </returns>
3504  /**/
3505  task_status wait() const
3506  {
3507  if (!_M_Impl)
3508  {
3509  throw invalid_operation("wait() cannot be called on a default constructed task.");
3510  }
3511 
3512  return _M_Impl->_Wait();
3513  }
3514 
3515  /// <summary>
3516  /// Returns the result this task produced. If the task is not in a terminal state, a call to <c>get</c> will wait for the task to
3517  /// finish. This method does not return a value when called on a task with a <c>result_type</c> of <c>void</c>.
3518  /// </summary>
3519  /// <returns>
3520  /// The result of the task.
3521  /// </returns>
3522  /// <remarks>
3523  /// If the task is canceled, a call to <c>get</c> will throw a <see cref="task_canceled Class">task_canceled</see> exception. If the task
3524  /// encountered an different exception or an exception was propagated to it from an antecedent task, a call to <c>get</c> will throw that exception.
3525  /// </remarks>
3526  /**/
3527  _ReturnType get() const
3528  {
3529  if (!_M_Impl)
3530  {
3531  throw invalid_operation("get() cannot be called on a default constructed task.");
3532  }
3533 
3534  if (_M_Impl->_Wait() == canceled)
3535  {
3536  throw task_canceled();
3537  }
3538 
3539  return _M_Impl->_GetResult();
3540  }
3541 
3542  /// <summary>
3543  /// Determines if the task is completed.
3544  /// </summary>
3545  /// <returns>
3546  /// True if the task has completed, false otherwise.
3547  /// </returns>
3548  /// <remarks>
3549  /// The function returns true if the task is completed or canceled (with or without user exception).
3550  /// </remarks>
3551  bool is_done() const
3552  {
3553  if (!_M_Impl)
3554  {
3555  throw invalid_operation("is_done() cannot be called on a default constructed task.");
3556  }
3557 
3558  return _M_Impl->_IsDone();
3559  }
3560 
3561  /// <summary>
3562  /// Returns the scheduler for this task
3563  /// </summary>
3564  /// <returns>
3565  /// A pointer to the scheduler
3566  /// </returns>
3567  scheduler_ptr scheduler() const
3568  {
3569  if (!_M_Impl)
3570  {
3571  throw invalid_operation("scheduler() cannot be called on a default constructed task.");
3572  }
3573 
3574  return _M_Impl->_GetScheduler();
3575  }
3576 
3577  /// <summary>
3578  /// Determines whether the task unwraps a Windows Runtime <c>IAsyncInfo</c> interface or is descended from such a task.
3579  /// </summary>
3580  /// <returns>
3581  /// <c>true</c> if the task unwraps an <c>IAsyncInfo</c> interface or is descended from such a task, <c>false</c> otherwise.
3582  /// </returns>
3583  /**/
3584  bool is_apartment_aware() const
3585  {
3586  if (!_M_Impl)
3587  {
3588  throw invalid_operation("is_apartment_aware() cannot be called on a default constructed task.");
3589  }
3590  return _M_Impl->_IsApartmentAware();
3591  }
3592 
3593  /// <summary>
3594  /// Determines whether two <c>task</c> objects represent the same internal task.
3595  /// </summary>
3596  /// <returns>
3597  /// <c>true</c> if the objects refer to the same underlying task, and <c>false</c> otherwise.
3598  /// </returns>
3599  /**/
3600  bool operator==(const task<_ReturnType>& _Rhs) const
3601  {
3602  return (_M_Impl == _Rhs._M_Impl);
3603  }
3604 
3605  /// <summary>
3606  /// Determines whether two <c>task</c> objects represent different internal tasks.
3607  /// </summary>
3608  /// <returns>
3609  /// <c>true</c> if the objects refer to different underlying tasks, and <c>false</c> otherwise.
3610  /// </returns>
3611  /**/
3612  bool operator!=(const task<_ReturnType>& _Rhs) const
3613  {
3614  return !operator==(_Rhs);
3615  }
3616 
3617  /// <summary>
3618  /// Create an underlying task implementation.
3619  /// </summary>
3620  void _CreateImpl(details::_CancellationTokenState * _Ct, scheduler_ptr _Scheduler)
3621  {
3622  _ASSERTE(_Ct != nullptr);
3623  _M_Impl = details::_Task_ptr<_ReturnType>::_Make(_Ct, _Scheduler);
3624  if (_Ct != details::_CancellationTokenState::_None())
3625  {
3626  _M_Impl->_RegisterCancellation(_M_Impl);
3627  }
3628  }
3629 
3630  /// <summary>
3631  /// Return the underlying implementation for this task.
3632  /// </summary>
3633  const typename details::_Task_ptr<_ReturnType>::_Type & _GetImpl() const
3634  {
3635  return _M_Impl;
3636  }
3637 
3638  /// <summary>
3639  /// Set the implementation of the task to be the supplied implementaion.
3640  /// </summary>
3641  void _SetImpl(const typename details::_Task_ptr<_ReturnType>::_Type & _Impl)
3642  {
3643  _ASSERTE(!_M_Impl);
3644  _M_Impl = _Impl;
3645  }
3646 
3647  /// <summary>
3648  /// Set the implementation of the task to be the supplied implementaion using a move instead of a copy.
3649  /// </summary>
3650  void _SetImpl(typename details::_Task_ptr<_ReturnType>::_Type && _Impl)
3651  {
3652  _ASSERTE(!_M_Impl);
3653  _M_Impl = std::move(_Impl);
3654  }
3655 
3656  /// <summary>
3657  /// Sets a property determining whether the task is apartment aware.
3658  /// </summary>
3659  void _SetAsync(bool _Async = true)
3660  {
3661  _GetImpl()->_SetAsync(_Async);
3662  }
3663 
3664  /// <summary>
3665  /// Sets a field in the task impl to the return callstack for calls to the task constructors and the then method.
3666  /// </summary>
3667  void _SetTaskCreationCallstack(const details::_TaskCreationCallstack &_callstack)
3668  {
3669  _GetImpl()->_SetTaskCreationCallstack(_callstack);
3670  }
3671 
3672  /// <summary>
3673  /// An internal version of then that takes additional flags and always execute the continuation inline by default.
3674  /// When _ForceInline is set to false, continuations inlining will be limited to default _DefaultAutoInline.
3675  /// This function is Used for runtime internal continuations only.
3676  /// </summary>
3677  template<typename _Function>
3678  auto _Then(const _Function& _Func, details::_CancellationTokenState *_PTokenState,
3679  details::_TaskInliningMode_t _InliningMode = details::_ForceInline) const -> typename details::_ContinuationTypeTraits<_Function, _ReturnType>::_TaskOfType
3680  {
3681  // inherit from antecedent
3682  auto _Scheduler = _GetImpl()->_GetScheduler();
3683 
3684  return _ThenImpl<_ReturnType, _Function>(_Func, _PTokenState, task_continuation_context::use_default(), _Scheduler, _CAPTURE_CALLSTACK(), _InliningMode);
3685  }
3686 
3687 private:
3688  template <typename T> friend class task;
3689 
3690 
3691  // The task handle type used to construct an 'initial task' - a task with no dependents.
3692  template <typename _InternalReturnType, typename _Function, typename _TypeSelection>
3693  struct _InitialTaskHandle :
3694  details::_PPLTaskHandle<_ReturnType, _InitialTaskHandle<_InternalReturnType, _Function, _TypeSelection>, details::_UnrealizedChore_t>
3695  {
3696  _Function _M_function;
3697  _InitialTaskHandle(const typename details::_Task_ptr<_ReturnType>::_Type & _TaskImpl, const _Function & _func)
3698  : details::_PPLTaskHandle<_ReturnType, _InitialTaskHandle<_InternalReturnType, _Function, _TypeSelection>, details::_UnrealizedChore_t>::_PPLTaskHandle(_TaskImpl)
3699  , _M_function(_func)
3700  {
3701  }
3702 
3703  virtual ~_InitialTaskHandle() {}
3704 
3705  template <typename _Func>
3706  auto _LogWorkItemAndInvokeUserLambda(_Func && _func) const -> decltype(_func())
3707  {
3708  details::_TaskWorkItemRAIILogger _LogWorkItem(this->_M_pTask->_M_taskEventLogger);
3709  CASABLANCA_UNREFERENCED_PARAMETER(_LogWorkItem);
3710  return _func();
3711  }
3712 
3713  void _Perform() const
3714  {
3715  _Init(_TypeSelection());
3716  }
3717 
3718  void _SyncCancelAndPropagateException() const
3719  {
3720  this->_M_pTask->_Cancel(true);
3721  }
3722 
3723  //
3724  // Overload 0: returns _InternalReturnType
3725  //
3726  // This is the most basic task with no unwrapping
3727  //
3728  void _Init(details::_TypeSelectorNoAsync) const
3729  {
3730  this->_M_pTask->_FinalizeAndRunContinuations(_LogWorkItemAndInvokeUserLambda(_Init_func_transformer<_InternalReturnType>::_Perform(_M_function)));
3731  }
3732 
3733  //
3734  // Overload 1: returns IAsyncOperation<_InternalReturnType>^ (only uder /ZW)
3735  // or
3736  // returns task<_InternalReturnType>
3737  //
3738  // This is task whose functor returns an async operation or a task which will be unwrapped for continuation
3739  // Depending on the output type, the right _AsyncInit gets invoked
3740  //
3741  void _Init(details::_TypeSelectorAsyncOperationOrTask) const
3742  {
3743  details::_Task_impl_base::_AsyncInit<_ReturnType, _InternalReturnType>(this->_M_pTask, _LogWorkItemAndInvokeUserLambda(_M_function));
3744  }
3745 
3746 #if defined (__cplusplus_winrt)
3747  //
3748  // Overload 2: returns IAsyncAction^
3749  //
3750  // This is task whose functor returns an async action which will be unwrapped for continuation
3751  //
3752  void _Init(details::_TypeSelectorAsyncAction) const
3753  {
3754  details::_Task_impl_base::_AsyncInit<_ReturnType, _InternalReturnType>(this->_M_pTask, ref new details::_IAsyncActionToAsyncOperationConverter(_LogWorkItemAndInvokeUserLambda(_M_function)));
3755  }
3756 
3757  //
3758  // Overload 3: returns IAsyncOperationWithProgress<_InternalReturnType, _ProgressType>^
3759  //
3760  // This is task whose functor returns an async operation with progress which will be unwrapped for continuation
3761  //
3762  void _Init(details::_TypeSelectorAsyncOperationWithProgress) const
3763  {
3764  typedef details::_GetProgressType<decltype(_M_function())>::_Value _ProgressType;
3765 
3766  details::_Task_impl_base::_AsyncInit<_ReturnType, _InternalReturnType>(this->_M_pTask,
3767  ref new details::_IAsyncOperationWithProgressToAsyncOperationConverter<_InternalReturnType,_ProgressType>(_LogWorkItemAndInvokeUserLambda(_M_function)));
3768  }
3769 
3770  //
3771  // Overload 4: returns IAsyncActionWithProgress<_ProgressType>^
3772  //
3773  // This is task whose functor returns an async action with progress which will be unwrapped for continuation
3774  //
3775  void _Init(details::_TypeSelectorAsyncActionWithProgress) const
3776  {
3777  typedef details::_GetProgressType<decltype(_M_function())>::_Value _ProgressType;
3778 
3779  details::_Task_impl_base::_AsyncInit<_ReturnType, _InternalReturnType>(this->_M_pTask,
3780  ref new details::_IAsyncActionWithProgressToAsyncOperationConverter<_ProgressType>(_LogWorkItemAndInvokeUserLambda(_M_function)));
3781  }
3782 #endif /* defined (__cplusplus_winrt) */
3783  };
3784 
3785 
3786  /// <summary>
3787  /// The task handle type used to create a 'continuation task'.
3788  /// </summary>
3789  template <typename _InternalReturnType, typename _ContinuationReturnType, typename _Function, typename _IsTaskBased, typename _TypeSelection>
3790  struct _ContinuationTaskHandle :
3791  details::_PPLTaskHandle<typename details::_NormalizeVoidToUnitType<_ContinuationReturnType>::_Type,
3792  _ContinuationTaskHandle<_InternalReturnType, _ContinuationReturnType, _Function, _IsTaskBased, _TypeSelection>, details::_ContinuationTaskHandleBase>
3793  {
3794  typedef typename details::_NormalizeVoidToUnitType<_ContinuationReturnType>::_Type _NormalizedContinuationReturnType;
3795 
3796  typename details::_Task_ptr<_ReturnType>::_Type _M_ancestorTaskImpl;
3797  _Function _M_function;
3798 
3799  _ContinuationTaskHandle(const typename details::_Task_ptr<_ReturnType>::_Type & _AncestorImpl,
3800  const typename details::_Task_ptr<_NormalizedContinuationReturnType>::_Type & _ContinuationImpl,
3801  const _Function & _Func, const task_continuation_context & _Context, details::_TaskInliningMode_t _InliningMode)
3802  : details::_PPLTaskHandle<typename details::_NormalizeVoidToUnitType<_ContinuationReturnType>::_Type,
3803  _ContinuationTaskHandle<_InternalReturnType, _ContinuationReturnType, _Function, _IsTaskBased, _TypeSelection>, details::_ContinuationTaskHandleBase>
3804  ::_PPLTaskHandle(_ContinuationImpl)
3805  , _M_ancestorTaskImpl(_AncestorImpl)
3806  , _M_function(_Func)
3807  {
3808  this->_M_isTaskBasedContinuation = _IsTaskBased::value;
3809  this->_M_continuationContext = _Context;
3810  this->_M_continuationContext._Resolve(_AncestorImpl->_IsApartmentAware());
3811  this->_M_inliningMode = _InliningMode;
3812  }
3813 
3814  virtual ~_ContinuationTaskHandle() {}
3815 
3816  template <typename _Func, typename _Arg>
3817  auto _LogWorkItemAndInvokeUserLambda(_Func && _func, _Arg && _value) const -> decltype(_func(std::forward<_Arg>(_value)))
3818  {
3819  details::_TaskWorkItemRAIILogger _LogWorkItem(this->_M_pTask->_M_taskEventLogger);
3820  CASABLANCA_UNREFERENCED_PARAMETER(_LogWorkItem);
3821  return _func(std::forward<_Arg>(_value));
3822  }
3823 
3824  void _Perform() const
3825  {
3826  _Continue(_IsTaskBased(), _TypeSelection());
3827  }
3828 
3829  void _SyncCancelAndPropagateException() const
3830  {
3831  if (_M_ancestorTaskImpl->_HasUserException())
3832  {
3833  // If the ancestor encountered an exception, transfer the exception to the continuation
3834  // This traverses down the tree to propagate the exception.
3835  this->_M_pTask->_CancelWithExceptionHolder(_M_ancestorTaskImpl->_GetExceptionHolder(), true);
3836  }
3837  else
3838  {
3839  // If the ancestor was canceled, then your own execution should be canceled.
3840  // This traverses down the tree to cancel it.
3841  this->_M_pTask->_Cancel(true);
3842  }
3843  }
3844 
3845  //
3846  // Overload 0-0: _InternalReturnType -> _TaskType
3847  //
3848  // This is a straight task continuation which simply invokes its target with the ancestor's completion argument
3849  //
3850  void _Continue(std::false_type, details::_TypeSelectorNoAsync) const
3851  {
3852  this->_M_pTask->_FinalizeAndRunContinuations(
3853  _LogWorkItemAndInvokeUserLambda(_Continuation_func_transformer<_InternalReturnType, _ContinuationReturnType>::_Perform(_M_function), _M_ancestorTaskImpl->_GetResult()));
3854  }
3855 
3856  //
3857  // Overload 0-1: _InternalReturnType -> IAsyncOperation<_TaskType>^ (only uder /ZW)
3858  // or
3859  // _InternalReturnType -> task<_TaskType>
3860  //
3861  // This is a straight task continuation which returns an async operation or a task which will be unwrapped for continuation
3862  // Depending on the output type, the right _AsyncInit gets invoked
3863  //
3864  void _Continue(std::false_type, details::_TypeSelectorAsyncOperationOrTask) const
3865  {
3866  typedef typename details::_FunctionTypeTraits<_Function, _InternalReturnType>::_FuncRetType _FuncOutputType;
3867 
3868  details::_Task_impl_base::_AsyncInit<_NormalizedContinuationReturnType, _ContinuationReturnType>(
3869  this->_M_pTask,
3870  _LogWorkItemAndInvokeUserLambda(_Continuation_func_transformer<_InternalReturnType, _FuncOutputType>::_Perform(_M_function), _M_ancestorTaskImpl->_GetResult())
3871  );
3872  }
3873 
3874 #if defined (__cplusplus_winrt)
3875  //
3876  // Overload 0-2: _InternalReturnType -> IAsyncAction^
3877  //
3878  // This is a straight task continuation which returns an async action which will be unwrapped for continuation
3879  //
3880  void _Continue(std::false_type, details::_TypeSelectorAsyncAction) const
3881  {
3882  typedef details::_FunctionTypeTraits<_Function, _InternalReturnType>::_FuncRetType _FuncOutputType;
3883 
3884  details::_Task_impl_base::_AsyncInit<_NormalizedContinuationReturnType, _ContinuationReturnType>(
3885  this->_M_pTask,
3886  ref new details::_IAsyncActionToAsyncOperationConverter(
3887  _LogWorkItemAndInvokeUserLambda(_Continuation_func_transformer<_InternalReturnType, _FuncOutputType>::_Perform(_M_function), _M_ancestorTaskImpl->_GetResult())));
3888  }
3889 
3890  //
3891  // Overload 0-3: _InternalReturnType -> IAsyncOperationWithProgress<_TaskType, _ProgressType>^
3892  //
3893  // This is a straight task continuation which returns an async operation with progress which will be unwrapped for continuation
3894  //
3895  void _Continue(std::false_type, details::_TypeSelectorAsyncOperationWithProgress) const
3896  {
3897  typedef details::_FunctionTypeTraits<_Function, _InternalReturnType>::_FuncRetType _FuncOutputType;
3898 
3899  auto _OpWithProgress = _LogWorkItemAndInvokeUserLambda(_Continuation_func_transformer<_InternalReturnType, _FuncOutputType>::_Perform(_M_function), _M_ancestorTaskImpl->_GetResult());
3900  typedef details::_GetProgressType<decltype(_OpWithProgress)>::_Value _ProgressType;
3901 
3902  details::_Task_impl_base::_AsyncInit<_NormalizedContinuationReturnType, _ContinuationReturnType>(
3903  this->_M_pTask,
3904  ref new details::_IAsyncOperationWithProgressToAsyncOperationConverter<_ContinuationReturnType, _ProgressType>(_OpWithProgress));
3905  }
3906 
3907  //
3908  // Overload 0-4: _InternalReturnType -> IAsyncActionWithProgress<_ProgressType>^
3909  //
3910  // This is a straight task continuation which returns an async action with progress which will be unwrapped for continuation
3911  //
3912  void _Continue(std::false_type, details::_TypeSelectorAsyncActionWithProgress) const
3913  {
3914  typedef details::_FunctionTypeTraits<_Function, _InternalReturnType>::_FuncRetType _FuncOutputType;
3915 
3916  auto _OpWithProgress = _LogWorkItemAndInvokeUserLambda(_Continuation_func_transformer<_InternalReturnType, _FuncOutputType>::_Perform(_M_function), _M_ancestorTaskImpl->_GetResult());
3917  typedef details::_GetProgressType<decltype(_OpWithProgress)>::_Value _ProgressType;
3918 
3919  details::_Task_impl_base::_AsyncInit<_NormalizedContinuationReturnType, _ContinuationReturnType>(
3920  this->_M_pTask,
3921  ref new details::_IAsyncActionWithProgressToAsyncOperationConverter<_ProgressType>(_OpWithProgress));
3922  }
3923 
3924 #endif /* defined (__cplusplus_winrt) */
3925 
3926  //
3927  // Overload 1-0: task<_InternalReturnType> -> _TaskType
3928  //
3929  // This is an exception handling type of continuation which takes the task rather than the task's result.
3930  //
3931  void _Continue(std::true_type, details::_TypeSelectorNoAsync) const
3932  {
3933  typedef task<_InternalReturnType> _FuncInputType;
3934  task<_InternalReturnType> _ResultTask;
3935  _ResultTask._SetImpl(std::move(_M_ancestorTaskImpl));
3936  this->_M_pTask->_FinalizeAndRunContinuations(
3937  _LogWorkItemAndInvokeUserLambda(_Continuation_func_transformer<_FuncInputType, _ContinuationReturnType>::_Perform(_M_function), std::move(_ResultTask)));
3938  }
3939 
3940  //
3941  // Overload 1-1: task<_InternalReturnType> -> IAsyncOperation<_TaskType>^
3942  // or
3943  // task<_TaskType>
3944  //
3945  // This is an exception handling type of continuation which takes the task rather than
3946  // the task's result. It also returns an async operation or a task which will be unwrapped
3947  // for continuation
3948  //
3949  void _Continue(std::true_type, details::_TypeSelectorAsyncOperationOrTask) const
3950  {
3951  // The continuation takes a parameter of type task<_Input>, which is the same as the ancestor task.
3952  task<_InternalReturnType> _ResultTask;
3953  _ResultTask._SetImpl(std::move(_M_ancestorTaskImpl));
3954  details::_Task_impl_base::_AsyncInit<_NormalizedContinuationReturnType, _ContinuationReturnType>(this->_M_pTask,
3955  _LogWorkItemAndInvokeUserLambda(_M_function, std::move(_ResultTask)));
3956  }
3957 
3958 #if defined (__cplusplus_winrt)
3959 
3960  //
3961  // Overload 1-2: task<_InternalReturnType> -> IAsyncAction^
3962  //
3963  // This is an exception handling type of continuation which takes the task rather than
3964  // the task's result. It also returns an async action which will be unwrapped for continuation
3965  //
3966  void _Continue(std::true_type, details::_TypeSelectorAsyncAction) const
3967  {
3968  // The continuation takes a parameter of type task<_Input>, which is the same as the ancestor task.
3969  task<_InternalReturnType> _ResultTask;
3970  _ResultTask._SetImpl(std::move(_M_ancestorTaskImpl));
3971  details::_Task_impl_base::_AsyncInit<_NormalizedContinuationReturnType, _ContinuationReturnType>(this->_M_pTask,
3972  ref new details::_IAsyncActionToAsyncOperationConverter(_LogWorkItemAndInvokeUserLambda(_M_function, std::move(_ResultTask))));
3973  }
3974 
3975  //
3976  // Overload 1-3: task<_InternalReturnType> -> IAsyncOperationWithProgress<_TaskType, _ProgressType>^
3977  //
3978  // This is an exception handling type of continuation which takes the task rather than
3979  // the task's result. It also returns an async operation with progress which will be unwrapped
3980  // for continuation
3981  //
3982  void _Continue(std::true_type, details::_TypeSelectorAsyncOperationWithProgress) const
3983  {
3984  // The continuation takes a parameter of type task<_Input>, which is the same as the ancestor task.
3985  task<_InternalReturnType> _ResultTask;
3986  _ResultTask._SetImpl(std::move(_M_ancestorTaskImpl));
3987 
3988  typedef details::_GetProgressType<decltype(_M_function(_ResultTask))>::_Value _ProgressType;
3989 
3990  details::_Task_impl_base::_AsyncInit<_NormalizedContinuationReturnType, _ContinuationReturnType>(this->_M_pTask,
3991  ref new details::_IAsyncOperationWithProgressToAsyncOperationConverter<_ContinuationReturnType, _ProgressType>(
3992  _LogWorkItemAndInvokeUserLambda(_M_function, std::move(_ResultTask))));
3993  }
3994 
3995  //
3996  // Overload 1-4: task<_InternalReturnType> -> IAsyncActionWithProgress<_ProgressType>^
3997  //
3998  // This is an exception handling type of continuation which takes the task rather than
3999  // the task's result. It also returns an async operation with progress which will be unwrapped
4000  // for continuation
4001  //
4002  void _Continue(std::true_type, details::_TypeSelectorAsyncActionWithProgress) const
4003  {
4004  // The continuation takes a parameter of type task<_Input>, which is the same as the ancestor task.
4005  task<_InternalReturnType> _ResultTask;
4006  _ResultTask._SetImpl(std::move(_M_ancestorTaskImpl));
4007 
4008  typedef details::_GetProgressType<decltype(_M_function(_ResultTask))>::_Value _ProgressType;
4009
